arm_group.description: The exercise training program was comprised of three 60-minute exercise sessions per week over a 3-month period.  Each exercise session consisted of a 5 minute warm up, 30-50 minutes of aerobic exercise performed on a treadmill and 5 minutes of cool-down exercises. Aerobic exercise intensity was set at the corresponding heart rate between the VAT and RCP.

The exercise training program was comprised of three 60-minute exercise sessions per week over a 3-month period.  Each exercise session consisted of a 5 minute warm up, 30-50 minutes of aerobic exercise performed on a treadmill and 5 minutes of cool-down exercises. Aerobic exercise intensity was set at the corresponding heart rate between the VAT and RCP. All patients were able to achieve the set aerobic training intensity.

The exercise training program was comprised of three 60-minute exercise sessions per week over a 3-month period.  Each exercise session consisted of a 5 minute warm up, 30-50 minutes of aerobic exercise performed on a treadmill . Aerobic exercise intensity was set at the corresponding heart rate between the VAT and RCP. All patients were able to achieve the set aerobic training intensity.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the present study was to test the hypothesis that patients with coronary
      artery disease with lower aerobic fitness exhibit greater responsiveness on improving
      ventilatory efficiency after aerobic exercise training.

clinical_study.brief_title: Aerobic Exercise on Ventilatory Efficiency in CAD Patients

detailed_description.textblock:
Measurements of ventilatory efficiency during cardiorespiratory exercise testing typically
      expressed as the minute ventilation/ carbon dioxide production ratio have been validated to
      be useful in assessing the presence and severity of both heart and lung diseases.  In this
      context, previous studies have showed ventilatory inefficiency in patients with coronary
      artery disease suggests abnormalities in the distribution of ventilation and perfusion in
      the lungs. In addition, a growing body of studies has demonstrated that lower ventilatory
      efficiency during exercise is considered an important predictor of risk mortality,
      hospitalization, and other outcomes than peak VO2.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  was stable coronary artery disease diagnosed by coronary angiography

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  unstable angina pectoris,

          -  complex ventricular arrhythmias,

          -  pulmonary congestion and

          -  orthopaedic or neurological limitations to exercise

intervention.description: The exercise training program was comprised of three 60-minute exercise sessions per week over a 3-month period.  Each exercise session consisted of a 5 minute warm up, 30-50 minutes of aerobic exercise performed on a treadmill and 5 minutes of cool-down exercises. Aerobic exercise intensity was set at the corresponding heart rate between the VAT and RCP. All patients were able to achieve the set aerobic training intensity.

clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Aerobic Exercise Training on Ventilatory Efficiency in Patients With Coronary Artery Disease

primary_outcome.description: Measurements of ventilatory efficiency during cardiopulmonary exercise testing typically expressed as the minute ventilation/ carbon dioxide production ratio have been validated to be useful in assessing the presence and severity of both heart  and lung diseases. In this context, previous studies have showed ventilatory inefficiency in patients with coronary artery disease suggests abnormalities in the distribution of ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.
primary_outcome.measure: Ventilatory efficiency in patients with coronary artery disease
primary_outcome.time_frame: up to 3 months of the interventions

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
